pageContext.claim: “I think we have close to 800,000 pending lawsuits [immigration cases]. And what happens -- these people disappear into the United States, never to show up for their case, which ends up coming back in about three, four years, five years, and even longer. It is the most ridiculous system.”
pageContext.analysis: There are 775,510 pending immigration cases in the United States as of November 2018, according to Syracuse University’s Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse (TRAC). But TRAC says the number is actually near 1.1 million because the Trump administration recently removed 330,211 previously completed cases and put them back on the “pending” rolls. So essentially the caseload has doubled during the Trump administration. The Justice Department reports that 72 percent of immigrants showed up for their hearings in fiscal 2017, including 89 percent of asylum-seekers.
